title: The Sleeping Dragon
description: Built in 1940, this 27-meter-long kiln is the oldest surviving "Dragon Kiln" in Singapore. Its long, sloped body acts like a chimney, creating the natural draft needed to reach extreme temperatures.

title: A 1260°C Fire
description: To turn raw clay into durable stoneware, the kiln must reach a staggering 1260°C. Maintaining this heat requires a team of potters to feed the "dragon" with wood every few minutes for over 24 hours straight.

title: The "Ash Glaze" Magic
description: Unlike electric kilns, wood-firing creates a natural "fly-ash" glaze. The wood ash settles on the pottery during the firing and melts, creating unique textures and colors that can never be replicated.

title: Five Generations of Fire
description: Owned by the Tan family since 1965, the kiln represents five generations of pottery heritage. It’s not just a tool; it’s a living museum of Singapore’s industrial and cultural history.

title: The Cooling Breath
description: After the firing is complete, the dragon needs to "rest." It takes about 2 to 3 days for the kiln to cool down before the potters can step inside to reveal the fired treasures.
